instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
Computer just stopped switching on.
Just beeping around the board for now and checking voltages:
Found short at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> <CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C6996</CAPACITOR> - replaced them all, short gone, but still not switching on, no green light no red light
Looking at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, 16.5v is going to pin 2, 16.1v is getting to pin 26 from from <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR>, less than 1v is getting to pin 1 from <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> so am I replacing this and checking again? I only ask as the schematic does not mention voltages coming from <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> or <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> only going into them.
Thanks

I am also thinking isl 6259 needs replacing, but I want to know bout <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> first. Checking pins 27 - 28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and pin 19-20 all is well.
Thanks

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: PP3V42 g3h present?

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: First mention of it I see on the schematic is pin 5 at <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> and it is not there. Checking it at pin 2 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and it is not there either. The place I get anything near that is 3.71v at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> pin 2 and pin 8. For what it is worth, when power is connected and I am testing for voltages, there is a ticking/spark noise coming from the board maybe an inch below F4260.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
After more looking:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> pin 4 gives out 16.8v and the same voltage gets to pin 26 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> pin 4 gives out 6.8v gets to pin 1 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> with the voltage at 0v - 0.4v
Looking at the details on the schematic for <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> I am thinking <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is good and <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> is bad. I am looking on scrap board to replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> and fit a new <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and see what happens.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: [COLOR=#FF8C00][U][B][SIZE=20px]Stop doing anything until you fix pp3v42 first.[/SIZE][/B][/U][/COLOR][SIZE=20px] [/SIZE][SIZE=12px]What is the voltage drop to ground on pin 2 of L6995? What is the voltage there?[/SIZE]

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: That is about 0.95v

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: really... so, which of the two questions i asked are you answering?

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: I am answering what is the voltage there. Each side of the country l measures 0.95v.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: Resistance to GND on L6995?

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: Red on ground, then black on each side of the coil gives a number of about 180

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
A normal value, in diode mode, is around .300 in that sense; much more inverting probes (black to ground).
Post voltages at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, 3, 4, 7, 8, 10.
Check for corroded traces, resolder <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> pins.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
Black to ground raises the number to nearly 190, but is little up and down. 
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> pins:
3 - 15.1v
4 - 16.6
7 - 16.6
8 - 3.75
10 - 0v
Reflowed the pins
3 - 15.1v
4 - 16.6
7 - 16.6
8 - 3.75
10 - 0v
No corroded traces

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: 190 is in diode mode? I need resistance in Ohm.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
Black on ground red on pin 1 - about 105 Ohms
Black on ground red on pin 2 - about 101 Ohms

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
That's not good at all; you must get more koms.
Even on diode mode can't be less than 290 (red on ground).
Reflow SMC and chech again; possible crap under it.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: Ive been thinking smc as well. Will reflow and check again. Computer isn't liquid damaged, but wadda you do.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: 100Ohm sucks as it is too low, but not low enough to cause anything to heat up. Did you check the infamous cap under the foam next to the BIL connector? You can inject 3.3V on the bus and see if your light turns green.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message:
I haven't heard of that no. Where is that on the board?
Thanks

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: Like I said, under the foam pad next to BIL connector. There is only one cap there that is on 3V42 rail. Maybe better to first inject external 3V3 on the rail and see if green light comes.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: I have found the foam by J6955, I will look for the cap and voltage.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: I can't find the cap the is on that line. What I have done is inject 3,3v at pin 10 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and it gave a current draw of 1.66a. L6995 after a few seconds was getting warm so I am looking at replacing that just to see what happens, then work up from there to find anything that might be dragging the voltage down.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: How would L6995 short to ground??

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: It can't, but it looks like something is dragging the voltage down or <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> is not producing the voltage.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: You injected the voltage at the wrong side of L6995. The current through L6995 is heating it up. Inject on other side and find something else that heats up.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: Remove first the cap mentioned by Duke; use boardview to identify it.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C6403</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> are the caps he's referring to. Also remove L6995 and inject 3.42v on pin 2 and see if you get a green light this way.

threads.title: 820 3115 board not switching on shorts found at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
threads.message: Thanks for the cap names, caps checked. Found no problems with them when checking them with red to ground and black on either side of them. L6995 removed injected 3.42v on pin 2, no green or red on charger, no fan spin. PSU gives current draw of between 1.5a and 2.5a. Board gently getting warm when power is injected for about 30 seconds. Looking for other issues on that line.
